event.name: event__initialize

form1.Title: Telemetry meeting report
form1.ClinDetailsText: Christian is a 33-year-old right-handed property developer. Christian was troubled by depression in his early 20s. 2009 - At age 26 years, he had stereotyped episodes with whistling, lip smacking, posturing of both arms and loss of awareness. He had these for 6 months then had a generalized seizure. Ongoing seizures with no period of remission Started on carbamazepine but caused headaches at low dosage. Changed to valproate which helped at 400mg/d. Lamotrigine added in which rendered him seizure-free for >1yr. Seizures returned in 2011. Lamotrigine increased to 200mg bd but not tolerated. Keppra added beneficially but caused anxiety and irritability. Oxcarbazapine added without improvement. He continues to have c. 5 CPS per month. Seen in clinic 31/08/16, Prof Duncan: Imp: Probable frontal lobe epilepsy based on EEG, 2009 Plan: 1) Epilepsy society at Chalfont (MRI, language fMRI, neuropsychology and neuropsychiatry) - DONE. NB fMRI ?L ?inconclusive 2) UCLH for FDG PET scan - DONE 3) Queen Square for video EEG telemetry - DONE

superclasstabrow2.Cell2: Rising epigastric sensation, nausea, pain in head and odd sensation (?depersonalisation in letter). He may retain awareness (he calls these 'auras') or he may become completely unaware of them unless checking the time or hearing from others. He has palpitations, shortness of breath and sweating. He may be scared. If he loses awareness, he may say phrases such as "I am going to die" or swear words ("F****** hell"). He maintains his posture and there is no head/eye deviation or automatisms.

sclasstabrow6.Cell2: Drowsy, thirsty, confused for up to 15 min. Language intact

superclasstabrow2.Cell2: Secondarily generalised seizures occurred at the outset and again in 2012 but not since. The description is that he will breathe heavily with eyes rolling, stiffness and juddering of all the limbs.

sclasstabrow5.Cell2: Documented to occur in 2009 and 2012 only

form1.PSHDetails: Depression since early 20s. 2016: "Christian’s mood is pervasively low with reduced enjoyment. He thinks about suicide but would not take active steps on account of his wife, step-daughter and the fact that his wife is expecting twins (Aug 2016)." SSRIs were not helpful in the past.
form1.SHDetails: Has been married for a year. He has a step daughter aged 7 and twin boys. He lost his driving licence recently and will have to take a taxi to the train station. Work is in London.

Row1.Cell4: Seizure-free for >1 yr on this initially but SEs at 200mg bd
Some help but limited by anxiety and irritability

EEGrow.Cell4: EEG, Hertford County, 15.5.2009: Prolonged runs of slow waves bifrontally, often intermixed with sharpened theta waves. EEG, Royal Free, 8.9.2009 : Left frontal lobe interictal epileptic discharges. Irregular bursts of high-voltage epileptiform spikes associated with irregular slow after discharges seen over the left frontal region with variable spread to the right.

VTRow.Cell4: VT-EEG, NHNN, 27.1.2017-3.2.2017 Interictal: Epileptiform: sharp waves, regional left frontotemporal, very rare Ictal: 1. Clinical sz: automotor sz (LOA) sz 1, 2 (out of camera),8 Lateralising signs: note: says single curse word during sz 2, some preserved responsiveness sz 8 Ictal tachycardia sz 2,8 EEG seizure regional left temporal, with propagation to the right 2. Clinical sz automotor (LOA) sz 3,4,5,6,7, Lateralising/localising signs: Sz 3,4 states afterwards he feels sick and short of breath, ictal water drinking sz 3, utters swear words, and “oh my god” (ictal speech), some preservation of responsiveness, but amnestic, slow in response, and after sz 6 unaware he even had a seizure. Ictal tachycardia in most; in many appears flushed in face, feeling of something stuck in the throat (sz 7) EEG sz: lateralised right hemisphere maximum frontotemporal

discussionform.Reviews: Psychiatry: At high risk of post-operative psychiatric morbidity, but already at high risk of self-harm. PET: No clear areas of hypometabolism MRI: Normal EEG: Onset in right hemisphere in some seizures; others appear to start in left hemisphere and spread to right

form1.Plan: Ictal SPECT Then will need intracranial EEG prior to considering surgery Con
form1.Name: C B

value.text: MRI, Lister, 12.5.2009: Completely normal. MRI, Chalfont, 16.12.16: There is slight image degradation, in particular on the coronal T2-weighted sequence allowing for which there is no convincing parenchymal abnormality. Cortico-white matter and ganglionic differentiation appears to be relatively preserved. There are one or two tiny nonspecific subcortical foci of T2 high signal within frontal white matter not unexpected or excessive for age, and of doubtful clinical consequence. PSR Hipposeg 91.6% Volume: Rt 3.05 Lt 2.79 T2: Automated Rt: 119.1 Lt: 116.5

fMRI, Chalfont, Prof Yousry, 16.12.16: Two language paradigms performed (verbal fluency and verb generation). Both paradigms activate anterior language areas bilaterally, left more than right. Verb generation activates small language areas bilaterally. There is no significant cerebellar activation. Conclusion: The activation pattern is inconclusive, indicating left hemispheric language dominance with some bilateral language representation.

FDG PET, UCH, 4.10.16: There is a subtle area of reduced metabolic activity in the left frontal lobe (PACS transaxial section, from top, 2nd row, last slice and second screen, 2nd row, 2nd slice), This subtle change is also noted on the Minoshima map where there is a tiny focus in the left frontal lobe inferiorly. Otherwise there is physiological cerebral distribution of FDG. Conclusion: Subtle reduction of metabolic activity in left frontal lobe.

Sallie Baxendale, 15.12.16: Mr Booth is currently functioning in the average range intellectually. His verbal reasoning skills are a relative weakness within his intellectual cognitive profile. He demonstrates significant verbal memory deficits, particularly in the learning and encoding of new verbal material. His visual memory was assessed to be intact, as were his language and executive functions. Overall, his profile would be consistent with a left temporal lobe focus for his epilepsy.

Gary Price, 16.12.16: History of depression in his twenties in reaction to family events of his father being unfaithful to his mother and his own girlfriend cheating on him. At this time superficially lacerated his thigh which gave him some relief. He denied doing this in his teen years and there are no other episodes of DSH or any suggestion of empty feelings and borderline traits. Currently has quite a persistent low mood with daily thoughts of life not worth living and easily bought to tears. No plans to kill himself and family are protective. We discussed that his mood is low and I mentioned that medication can be helpful. He does not want medication but will consider counselling and I have given him the contact details for self-referral for his local IAPT service.
